 with blue and black panels. The main body of the kain panjang is decorated with stylised bats
 winged animals

sgcool_label_text:Set against a cream background
 the ‘body’ of this kain panjang is decorated with bats
 symbolising good fortune in the Chinese tradition
 birds with elaborate plumage
 as well as flowering branches.  On the broad vertical panel (kepala)
 rows of interlocking triangles are filled with tiny rosettes and tendrils.  This batik comes from the family collection of Oey Djien Nio (1929-1987)
 the last in three generations of documented batik-makers in Pekalongan.  In her earlier signatures
 she used her husband’s name
 Liem Siok Hien.  But from 1965 onwards
 she used Jane Hendromartono
 combining her husband’s new Indonesian family name
 Hendromartono with Jane
 as people addressed her by.  She developed a personal style distinct from her mother and grandmother
 and experimented with a wide spectrum of colours and exotic combinations of birds
 rock formations and mythical animals.  Jane Hendromartono’s clientele expanded beyond the elite in Indonesia to include Europe
 America and Japan
 especially in the 1980s.  This piece is signed “Hendromartono’s Batik Art” Unique Pekalongan Indonesia”.

metadata.sgcool_label_text: Set against a cream background, the ‘body’ of this kain panjang is decorated with bats, symbolising good fortune in the Chinese tradition, birds with elaborate plumage, as well as flowering branches.  On the broad vertical panel (kepala), rows of interlocking triangles are filled with tiny rosettes and tendrils.  This batik comes from the family collection of Oey Djien Nio (1929-1987), the last in three generations of documented batik-makers in Pekalongan.  In her earlier signatures, she used her husband’s name, Liem Siok Hien.  But from 1965 onwards, she used Jane Hendromartono, combining her husband’s new Indonesian family name, Hendromartono with Jane, as people addressed her by.  She developed a personal style distinct from her mother and grandmother, and experimented with a wide spectrum of colours and exotic combinations of birds, rock formations and mythical animals.  Jane Hendromartono’s clientele expanded beyond the elite in Indonesia to include Europe, America and Japan, especially in the 1980s.  This piece is signed “Hendromartono’s Batik Art” Unique Pekalongan Indonesia”.
